intro: Monnina pterocarpa, commonly known as the winged bluemink, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Onagraceae, which includes species such as willows and evening primroses. The plant is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, blue to violet flowers that bloom in late spring. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its drought-resistant adaptations. The fruit is a capsule that splits open to release seeds, aiding in its propagation in arid environments.
